author: Alan Boyle
title: Itâ€™s a UFO! Itâ€™s a walnut? No â€¦ Itâ€™s Pan, one of Saturnâ€™s weirdest-looking moons
text:
A picture taken by the high-resolution camera on the Cassini orbiter shows Panâ€™s weird-looking equatorial ridge. (NASA / JPL-Caltech / SSI) Astronomers have long known that Pan, one of the â€œshepherd moonsâ€ in Saturnâ€™s rings, had a weird shape. But it took this weekâ€™s high-resolution images from the Cassini orbiter to show them just how weird.
Cassini got its closest look ever at Pan on Tuesday, when it came within a little more than 15,000 miles of the 20-mile-wide moon. In the close-ups released on Thursday, the thing looks like a flattened flying saucer, complete with a bulging ridge around the edge.
Overnight, the views sparked rounds of hilarity and awe on Twitter. Was it a cosmic turtle shell? Walnut? Ravioli? And whatâ€™s behind that strange, strange shape?
Homing in on one strange-looking moon in an alien system far, far away. All in a day's work for our wandering observer at 10 AU from the Sun pic.twitter.com/UgVAcj4Vgr 
â€” Carolyn Porco (@carolynporco) March 9, 2017 
@carolynporco Are you sure thatâ€™s not a tortellini? #Conspiracytheory 
â€” Andrew Dandilly (@Andrew_Dandilly) March 9, 2017 
Thatâ€™s itâ€¦Iâ€™m not fat, I have an accretionary equatorial bulge. ğŸ¤“ https://t.co/f9shsUMk0a 
â€” Angela Taylor (@PartPurple) March 9, 2017 
Weâ€™re in for some major suffering when this thing hatches. https://t.co/G0oCsBjTii 
â€” Paul Czege (@PaulCzege) March 9, 2017 
Did you see that â€œCosmicalâ€ updated? And itâ€™s all about Saturnâ€™s Ravioli moon! https://t.co/3NQyPj6tv1 #Saturn #Moon #Pan #NASA #Cassini pic.twitter.com/yBvdDj6MVU 
â€” Cosmical (@CosmicalComic) March 10, 2017 
Close-up of the celestial ravioli orbiting around Saturn. No news on whether itâ€™s filled with cheese or spinach. Still, itâ€™s awesome. https://t.co/jrB5lQwQAd 
â€” Nancy McGuire (@WordChem) March 9, 2017 
After 13 yrs, we've come to expect extreme reactions to our images. But hunger? Ravioli, tortellini, empanada, pierogi, hamburger, brie?
â€” Carolyn Porco (@carolynporco) March 9, 2017 
And here is 18-mile-wide Pan in its native environment, living in a gap in Saturnâ€™s rings. https://t.co/Q5N1nEyr2x pic.twitter.com/6BnRNW8mS9 
â€” Corey S. Powell (@coreyspowell) March 10, 2017 
Carolyn Porco, who leads the imaging team for the soon-to-be-concluded Cassini mission , pointed to a couple of papers published nearly a decade ago that explain why Pan (named after the pipe-playing shepherd god of Greek mythology) looks the way it does.
Like Saturnâ€™s other shepherd moons, Pan plies its way between sections of the giant planetâ€™s rings, clearing out a gap as it goes. In Panâ€™s case, thatâ€™s the Encke Gap of the A ring.
Panâ€™s gravitational field pulls in icy particles from the edge of the ring as it makes its rounds. Thatâ€™s how it helps keep the rings in shape, by â€œshepherdingâ€ stray ring particles. Some of that fine-grained material piles up around the saucer moonâ€™s middle to create a smooth, protruding ridge.
For what itâ€™s worth, Pan is by no means the only weirdo in the Saturnian system. Thereâ€™s Iapetus , a two-toned moon that has its own walnut-type ridge; Hyperion , a moon that looks like a giant sponge; and Mimas , the â€œDeath Starâ€ moon.
More planetary wonders from this week: 
Get out your red-blue glasses and check out the 3-D view of Ceresâ€™ white spots , which scientists now suspect are composed of carbonate salt deposits that accumulated over the course of millions of years. NASA says it has used ground-based radar to locate Indiaâ€™s Chandrayaan-1 moon-orbiting spacecraft , which has been out of contact since 2009. NASAâ€™s mission to study Europa, an ice-covered moon of Jupiter, now has an official name: Europa Clipper , a moniker that has been used unofficially in the past. The Europa Clipper mission will send a spacecraft to make repeated flybys of the moon in the 2020s, looking for further evidence of the potentially habitable ocean thatâ€™s thought to lie beneath the ice.
